The 19th century saw the rise of nationalism in the Balkans which resulted in the establishment of an independent Greece, Serbia andBulgaria. Most of the local Muslims in these countries suffered as many died during the conflicts and others fled. The persecution of Muslims was continued during World War I by the invading Russian troops in the east and the Caucasus and during the Turkish War of Independence in the west, east, and south of Anatolia. After the Greek-Turkish war, apopulation exchange took place and most Muslims in Greece left. During these centuries many Muslim refugees, called Muhacir, settled in Turkey. Some of them returned after the war but most of these left again. The Bulgarian Muslims (part of them Turks) settled mostly around the Sea of Marmara. Some of them had been wealthy and they played an important part in the Ottoman elite in later years. Almost half of the pre war 1,5 million Muslim population of Bulgaria was gone, an estimated 200,000 died and the rest fled.  On the eve of the outbreak of a second round of hostilities between Serbia and the Ottoman Empire in 1877, a notable Muslim population existed in the districts of Niš, Pirot, Vranje, Leskovac, Prokuplje and Kuršumlija. The rural parts of Toplica, Kosanica, Pusta Rekaand Jablanica valleys and adjoining semi-mountainous interior was inhabited by compact Muslim Albanian population while Serbs in those areas lived near the river mouths and mountain slopes and both peoples inhabited other regions of the South Morava river basin. The Muslim population of most of the area was composed out of ethnic Gheg Albanians and with Turks located in urban centres. Part of the Turks were of Albanian origin. The Muslims in the cities of Niš and Pirot were Turkish-speaking;Vranje and Leskovac were Turkish- and Albanian-speaking; Prokuplje and Kuršumlija were Albanian-speaking. There was also a minority of Circassian refugees settled by the Ottomans during the 1860s, near the then border around the environs of Niš. Estimates vary on the size of the Muslim population on the eve of the war within these areas ranging from as high as 200, 000 to as low as 131,000. Estimates as to the number of the Muslim refugees that left the region for the Ottoman Empire due to the war range from 60–70,000 to as low as 30,000. The departure of the Albanian population from these regions was done in a manner that today would be characterized as ethnic cleansing. Greeks are not aware of any of this, because it was a fringe view back then, as much as it is would be a fringe view nowadays. National liberation was the dominant political theory of most of the 19th and 20th centuries in the Balkans. Confederation as an alternative to that was always a minority view, and then, it only involved the subject nations of the Ottoman Empire, excluding the Turks, who were seen as the conqueror to be rid of before confederation could happen. The Jewish population of Thessaloniki were favourable to such an idea as well as some Socialists, as an alternative to the nationalist struggle of the Balkan Wars and WW1. But that always excluded the Turks. Once Turkish nationalism kicked in as a well and after the horrible atrocities of the Armenian and Pontian genocides and the 1921–22 Greco-Turkish war, any suggestion of confederation between Greeks and Turks would be regarded as high treason, after so much bad blood. Mentioning Venizelos as a proponent of Hellenoturkism would be a gross misrepresentation of what the man stood for through all his life, despite any quotation you may see. He was the prime instigator of the Cretan revolution of 1905 that ended Ottoman rule on the island. He presided over the Balkan Wars, WW1 and the beginning of the Greco-Turkish war as the primary politician in Greece urging for the fulfilment of Megali Idea. It is true that after he returned to power in 1928, he pushed for a normalisation of Greco-Turkish relations and managed to lead Greece and Turkey into their 1930 treaty and the 1934 Balkan non-aggression pact - the quotation mentioned by Wikipedia is in fact from that period. But the context at the time was two separate and homogenous nations who had little more to divide between them, so they might just as well get along. As for Kitsikis and Typaldos (that 19th century Cephallonian who also supported Hellenoturkism), they are absolutely obscure.
